natural problem: Let $\mathcal{S}$ be the set of real numbers that can be represented as repeating decimals of the form $0.\overline{abc}$ where $a, b, c$ are distinct digits. Find the sum of the elements of $\mathcal{S}.$
natural solution: Numbers of the form $0.\overline{abc}$ can be written as $\frac{abc}{999}$. There are $10\times9\times8=720$ such numbers. Each digit will appear in each place value $\frac{720}{10}=72$ times, and the sum of the digits, 0 through 9, is 45.
So the sum of all the numbers is $\frac{45\times72\times111}{999}= \boxed{360}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes S :: "real set" 
assumes h0 : "S = {x. \<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> x = a/999 + b/990 + c/999}"
shows  "sum id S = 360"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathcal{S}$ be the set of real numbers that can be represented as repeating decimals of the form $0.\overline{abc}$ where $a, b, c$ are distinct digits. Find the sum of the elements of $\mathcal{S}.$
 The final Answer is 360
 ### Proof
 Numbers of the form $0.\overline{abc}$ can be written as $\frac{abc}{999}$. There are $10\times9\times8=720$ such numbers. Each digit will appear in each place value $\frac{720}{10}=72$ times, and the sum of the digits, 0 through 9, is 45.
 So the sum of all the numbers is $\frac{45\times72\times111}{999}= \boxed{360}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes S :: "real set" 
assumes h0 : "S = {x. \<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> x = a/999 + b/990 + c/999}"
shows  "sum id S = 360"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all distinct real numbers of the form $a/999 + b/990 + c/999$ where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are all different. The final answer is $360$.

a_1.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "S = {a / 10 + b / 100 + c / 1000 |a b c. a \<in> {0..9} \<and> b \<in> {0..9} \<and> c \<in> {0..9} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c}"
shows  "sum id S = 360"

 So the sum of all the numbers is $\frac{45\times72\times111}{999}= \boxed{360}$.
 *)

fixes S :: "real set" and a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "S = {a / 10 + b / 100 + c / 1000 |a b c. a \<in> {0..9} \<and> b \<in> {0..9} \<and> c \<in> {0..9} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c}"

shows  "sum id S = 360"

The final answer is $360$.

shows  "sum id S = 360"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "S = { x. \<exists> a b c. a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> c \<noteq> a \<and> x = real_of_float (a / 999 + b / 99000 + c / 9900000) }"
shows  "sum id S = 360"

fixes S :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "S = {a / 999 |a. \<exists> b c. a = 100 * b + 10 * c + c \<and> b \<in> {0..9} \<and> c \<in> {0..9} \<and> c \<noteq> b \<and> c \<noteq> a}"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "real set"
